description: From Middle English leye, lye, from Old English lēah, lēag (“lye”), from Proto-West Germanic *laugu, from Proto-Germanic *laugō, from Proto-Indo-European *lewh₃- (“to wash”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian Loge, Looie (“lye”), Dutch loog (“lye”), German Low German Loge, Loje, Loog (“lye”), German Lauge (“lye”).

entries.meaning: An alkaline liquid made by leaching ashes (usually wood ashes).

verbs.description: lye (third-person singular simple present lyes, present participle lyeing or lying, simple past and past participle lyed)

description: Variant of lie (“to rest horizontally”) now used in a specialised sense; compare sett.

entries.meaning: (UK, rail transport) A short side line, connected with the main line; a turn-out; a siding.

verbs.description: lye (third-person singular simple present lyes, present participle lying, simple past lay, past participle lain or layn)

examples: Now negligent of sports I lye,And now as other Fawkners use,I spring a mistresse, sweare, write, sigh and weepe:And the game kill'd, or lost, goe talk, and sleepe.
